The greatest honor is to have your name in the periodic table. Only 15 people have it (20 if you count elements named after things which were in turn named after people):


-Curium (Marie and Pierre Curie/pioneers in the study of radioactivity / the only element named after 2 people) #96
-Einsteinium (Albert Einstein / Creator of the theories of general and special relativity) #99
-Fermium (Enrico Fermi / Creator of the first nuclear reactor and the architect of the nuclear age) #100
-Mendelevium (Dimitri Mendeleev / Creator of the periodic table) #101
-Nobelium (Alfred Nobel / Creator of Dynamite and the Nobel prize) #102
-Lawrencium (Ernest Lawrence / Creator of the cyclotron and pioneer in nuclear physics) #103
-Rutherfordium (Ernest Rutherford / Discoverer of the nucleus in the atom) #104
-Seaborgium (Glenn T. Seaborg / Discoverer of 10 elements) #106
-Bohrium (Niels Bohr / Discoverer of the electron orbitals in the atom) #107
-Meitnerium (Lise Meitner / Discoverer of nuclear fission) #109
-Roentgenium (Wilhelm Roentgen / Discoverer of the X-ray) #111
-Copernicium (Nicolaus Copernicus / Founder of the heliocentric solar system) #112
-Flerovium (Georgy Flyorov / Discoverer of spontaneous fission) #114
-Oganesson (Yuri Oganessiun / Inventor of cold fusion which led to the discovery of 12 new elements / the last known element) #118


Meanwhile, 5 people have their names in cities, continents, or minerals which had elements named after them:


-Samarium (the mineral samarskite / Vasili Samarsky-Bykhovets / the first person who's name was in the periodic table) #62
-Gadolinium (the mineral gadolinite / Johan Gadolin) # 64
-Americium (the continent of America / Amerigo Vespucci) #95
-Berkelium (The city Berkely / George Berkely) #97
-Livermorium (the city Livermore / Robert Livermore) #117

>mentions the Medal of Honor without mentioning Dan Daly

Ohh boy. Let me tell the tale of a man who won the Medal of Honor twice, and almost a third time, and lived to tell the tale. Every. Single. Time.

His first MoH was won during the Boxer Rebellion. PFC Daly was the sole Marine stationed in an entire city. One night, the enemy, a force of about 400 men, decided to attack. Using a machine gun, a bolt-action rifle, and a tripod, he fought off all of them at once. By morning, over 200 lay dead in front of the city gates.

The second was awarded during the occupation of Haiti. GySgt. Daly’s platoon was crossing a river when they were ambushed. In the confusion, the wagon carrying their only machine gun was lost in the water. They made it to the other side and set up camp. In the night, Daly snuck out and recovered the machine gun by himself, without any sort of light. In the morning, his unit was able to repel the enemy.

His third action, and arguably the one that should have gotten him an MoH as well as the Silver Star, was in WWI, during the Battle of Belleau Wood. 1Sgt. Daly’s men were fatigued and low on morale. They had been fighting for days and the Germans seemed like they would never stop. Suddenly, Daly jumped up with his rifle and shouted to them, “Come on, you sons of bitches! Do you want to live forever?” He proceeded to lead a successful charge which led to the Allies’ victory along the front.

You thought he was done? HAHAHA! During the same battle, he rushed to put out a fire in an ammo dump. An ammo dump that could’ve blown him sky high any second. He then went to look after several gun crews and captured a machine gun nest, again, solo, using his pistol and several grenades.
For this, he was awarded the Distinguished Service Medal and the Navy Cross.

And now he’s done.

Personally, I would say that the second definition is more "fame". The kind of "honor" that it talks about is more the idea that a large group of people generally consider you positively. Everybody might know what McDonald's is, but that doesn't mean that everyone eats there, or even that most of the people who do eat there have any particular approval for it as opposed to simply not having something they consider a better option.
For my part, I would say that the greatest "award" honor is the Nobel peace prize. I wouldn't consider anything else to be a more recognized award of its type, and it is something that I think many people would agree is both positive and meaningful, more than would agree on any othe type of award.

It was a minor comment in the video (7:15) , but I don't believe becoming a mother or father should be considered an honourable thing. The choice to have children is almost never a decision made for the sake of the child (the exceptions being certain foster/adoption cases where the parents did place more importance on the child's welfare than their own desires.)

I'd argue, in the case of biological offspring, that the decision is always driven by selfish reasons (albeit not necessarily from both parties). You can't exactly say "I want a kid for the sake of the kid," - at least not without numerous philosophical reverberations which I, for one, would find tough to reconcile.

I'm with Michael, in general (not to mention, he is pretty intelligent as humans go). I would like to express my idea of the greatest honour. I feel (notice, it seems relative to how we feel about it) that the greatest honour, is possibly virtuous self-condemnation. This may sound very strange, but let me explain. Not every person can live up to their own virtues... I am ashamed of my own inadequate ability (in serious situations), to have the courage necessary to follow my own virtues. I know I should defend the innocent, and should defend the right, but I have seen myself stand paralyzed when the moments came. I am intelligent, I am strong and of virtuous mind, but my physiology has not always been cooperative with my psychology. I have seen awful things happening to other people, and felt nothing but horror at my inability to act. I do not think there is anything about me, that I can surely respect, except that I have a mind honourable enough, that I can condemn nothing except myself. I do not blame anyone or anything, not even myself. But I condemn myself for those errors that have come from me, for those times I could have been a greater man. I know that I have done my best, and always do, but I cannot be proud of that. I can only respect that I condemn my own failures and errors, which is the only proof that I sought and seek to be more. Wouldn't a lot of us be superhuman if we could? wouldn't we be heroes if we could? I feel this one honour that is my own, that I mourn the pain of others, mourn that I am useless to those who need someone, those that need a hero. I am honoured to be, a hero wanna be. I am honoured to know that I will never respect myself, if I cannot be a man of honour, a man of my own virtues. I feel that there is a great honour in knowing, that no matter what you can or cannot do, there is something inside your mind that is cheering for the better, and cursing at the worse. Something that will not give you leniency from your own ethics or morals. Something that will say, "you were wrong, be ashamed of yourself, be humiliated". Perhaps I am speaking of the "conscience" that people often refer to, but whatever the case, that great thing inside you, that asks too much, and only rewards great virtue, an condemns immorality. There are few better ways to know yourself, than to hear yourself condemn yourself, for being less than yourself.

Her element is Honesty, and she is loyal to her family.

Humility = Fluttershy

Her element is Kindness, and she is a social butterfly (hence her cutie mark) who likes animals.
Humility means lack of vanity or pride, she shows humbleness and assumes unassertiveness, although there are times when he does the 'stare', or when she claims to be 'assertive', there was an episode where Fluttershy is made mean by Iron Will until she looks at her puddle reflection.

Hope = Rainbow Dash 

Her element is Loyalty, although sometimes she isn't that loyal according to some theories.
She claims to clear the sky in 'ten seconds flat'. She is also known for the quote '20% cooler', and sometimes people say that she is 'best pony'.

Humor = Pinkie Pie

Her element is Laughter, and sometimes she likes to party. Are you ready to party, Pinkamena Diane? (spongebob joke)
Her hair droops straight and her color dulls when she gets sad, and sometimes stir crazy. Hence the theory that she is related to the crystal ponies. Appreciation of Beauty = Rarity

Love of Learning = Twilight Sparkle

@Cory Dunstan Okay, first... pronunciation refers only to how you pronounce (say) a word, and not which word you use. Second, I've since learned that this is actually one of the hard rules of English, thank God. Not like i before e, except after c, and so many others which are broken in many cases.

The rule is that is depends on the sound of the immediately following word, period. ie: a one-eyed purple people eater. Even though one starts with a vowel, it's first sound is "w," because it is pronounced "won." Another example is, "an hour." The "h" is silent and a vowel sound starts the word.

That being said, you would not say, "An heroic event," because the "h" is clearly pronounced!

Sorces:

http://www.quickanddirtytips.com/education/grammar/a-versus-an?page=all
http://editingandwritingservices.com/a-or-an-before-words-beginning-with-h/

Well...I have to disagree with the hero in waiting theory, but will present my own theory on 'great men' that is not as luck based. I call it "Selection Cycle". It goes like this:
Society has a desire. They select an individual who they think will solve their problem. The individual then spurs society into action by giving them a desire to. The process then repeats itself.

For example, there's traffic jams. Society seeks out a person to solve this problem. They elect a mayor with this new idea: Stop signs. Society is persuaded to move into action, and put up stop signs. Then, people have trouble seeing stop signs in the dark. They seek out a person to solve this problem. They find a guy who invented the light bulb. He persuades people to build light bulbs and put them on the streets.

The Greatest Honor, is the honor that "God(s)" have. Statistically speaking God(s) has had the most acknowledgement compared to anyone throughout history. The power to create a world and creatures, upon different beliefs, is considered the greatest accomplishment. You don't have to be religious to realize this... I'm not.
--- The most printed and purchased books throughout history are ones containing religious beliefs and morals. People who read them usually respect and admire the religious morals in their contents. When you put a face, figure, apparition, or name on religion, you get a god.
--- People try to better themselves by reading the bible and learning from it. I haven't seen these people that Vsauce mentioned have books written about them.
~Ask yourself the question: If these people deserve such a great honor, why am  I going to forgot about them by the time I wake up again... and why do people keep "God" in mind everyday and remember that name?
--- Apparently the greatest honor doesn't have to exist to be the greatest honor. Maybe you can't put the honor on a god. Maybe it is just a person's thought of an exemplary person. Whether they exist or not, the dedication and admiration is still there.
- - - I guess you can argue that the honor is just hypothetical and it really comes from a person's self evaluation.

Assuming the room was completely sealed off from outside sources, i.e. no electromagnetic radiation can get in, it would depend on what kind of paint you used.
Typical glow-in-the-dark paint is phosphorescent, basically meaning it absorbs energy and then releases it slowly over time. So in a sealed room it wouldn't glow.

The original Latin was "honor." The French then used "o" or "u" interchangeably and sometimes left the "h" off, making "onur" an acceptable spelling. Middle English took "onur" and slipped the "h" and "o" back in in time for the dictionary mentioned in the video.
So Americans are using the original spelling, and anyone spelling it "honour" is using the most wrong spelling they can get away with, because someone thought extra letters looked cool.

1st, they belong to the Nightshade family. 2nd, Potatoes turn green when they’re exposed to sunlight. As the plant prepares for photosynthesis and sprouting (by producing green chlorophyll), it develops a bitter, poisonous chemical (solanine) to discourage hungry animals from eating it. The green color serves as a warning that toxic solanine is present. Incidentally, the stems and leaves of potato plants also contain solanine, which is why we don’t eat the greens.
